{{Infobox video game |title=Aztaka |image= |caption= |developer=Citérémis |publisher=Citérémis |designer= |series= |engine= |released=May 2009 |genre=[[Action role-playing game]], [[Metroidvania]]<ref>{{cite web | url = http://nl.ign.com/all/62504/feature/metroidvania-game-design-101 | title = Metroidvania: Game Design 101 | first = Rick | last = Otten | date = September 30, 2013 | accessdate = July 13, 2016 | publisher = [[IGN|IGN Benelux]] | quote = "Ook in het Westen hebben Metroidvania-fans echter niet stilgestaan. Zo was Aztaka bijvoorbeeld een erg interessant spelletje..." }}</ref> |modes=[[Single-player]] |platforms=[[Microsoft Windows]] & [[OS X]] }}
'''''Aztaka''''' is a [[Personal computer|PC]] [[2D computer graphics|2D]] [[Side-scrolling video game|side-scrolling]] [[action game|action]] [[role-playing video game]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[OS X]] developed by Canadian [[independent game developer]]<ref name="gamemachine"/> Citérémis. The game is set in the [[Aztec]] period, with characters and story being re-interpretations of [[Aztec mythology]] and [[pre-Hispanic]] [[Mexican culture]]. It puts the player in the role of an [[Aztec warfare|Aztec warrior]] named "Huitzilo" who must gather seven [[phonographs]] to save his civilization from its angry gods.
==Gameplay== [[File:Aztaka Skill Window.jpg|thumb|left|Game screenshot]]
The gameplay is reminiscent of an [[old school gaming|old-school]] [[action role-playing game]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} The player climbs, crawls and jumps his way around a level to explore it and find new items. Experience points are gained for every enemy killed, and they are spent to upgrade the character's attributes and special skills. There is also an inventory screen where discovered items can be equipped and where merchandise bought from merchants (like potions) can be used.
The game is controlled with the [[WASD keys]] and the mouse. The keyboard makes Huitzilo move and jump like in a [[platform game]]. The mouse is used to drag-and-drop on-screen energy particles. Doing this allows the player to modify parts of the game world, as well as unlock a variety of doorways or pick-up previously unattainable items. As the player progresses in the game, he gains containers that allows him to store on-screen energy particles for later use. The mouse is also used to cast spells, both offensive and defensive, by selecting them from the bottom-screen magic inventory and then clicking at on-screen targets in succession to launch them.
Artwork throughout the game reflects historical [[Mesoamerica]], with square-shaped pyramids, stone temples, mystic engravings, dense jungles, and barren mountaintops. The game's musical score features vocals, flute, cello, organ, and drums.
==Plot== {{expand section|date=September 2013}} The game is set in the [[Aztec]] period, with characters and story being re-interpretations of [[Aztec mythology]] and [[pre-Hispanic]] [[Mexican culture]]. Aztaka puts the player in the role of an [[Aztec warfare|Aztec warrior]] named "Huitzilo" who must gather seven phonographs to save his civilization from its angry gods.
==History== Aztaka was developed by Citérémis, a Canadian [[independent game developer]] with [[Game demo|demo releases]] publicly available in begin 2009.<ref name="aztakademo"/> The game was released as [[DRM-free]] [[digital distribution|digital self-distribution]] on the developer's website in May 2009.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100211135929/http://aztaka.citeremis.com/ Official game website] (archived)</ref><ref name="aztakademo"/> Later in 2009 the game was also sold also on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and [[Direct2Drive]].<ref name="aztakademo"/> In 2011, Citérémis offered a "Developer's Edition" for a limited period of time (7 to 31 January 2011).<ref name="revenue">[http://www.citeremis.com/citeremis-releases-aztaka-developers-edition/ citeremis-releases-aztaka-developers-edition/] on citeremis ''"The budget: $235,000 borrowed from friends and family who trusted them. Since its release in May 2009, Aztaka has received positive reviews by many websites, and has achieved total revenue of about $35,000. To bridge the gap: Aztaka Developer's Edition, that will only be available from Jan. 7th 9:00 AM (EST) until 11:59 PM on January 31st."'' (January 10, 2011)</ref> This edition was priced $19.99 (normal version $9.99) and included the [[source code]] of the game, as well as the [[Art book]] and [[soundtrack]].<ref>[http://amanita-design.net/blog/2011/01/07/aztaka-developers-edition/ Aztaka Developer’s Edition] on [[Amanita Design|amanitadesign.com]] (January 7, 2011)</ref><ref>[http://www.gamershell.com/news_108978.html Aztaka Developer's Edition Released] on gamershell.com (January 10, 2011)</ref>
In 2012 the game was part of a game [[Product bundling|bundle]] sale.<ref>[https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2012/06/19/twice-the-bundle-twice-the-uh-fundle/#more-112850 Twice The Bundle, Twice The, Uh, Fundle] by Alec Meer on [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] (June 19th, 2012)</ref>
==Reception== The game was received by press and game news websites overall good to mixed.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713130110/http://www.just-rpg.com/default.asp?pid=3475 ''Aztaka'' review] from Just-RPG.com (2009)</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20091124211922/http://diygamer.com/2009/11/rpg-platformer-baby-aztaka/ ''Aztaka'' review] from DIYGamer (2009)</ref><ref>[http://www.gamezebo.com/2009/06/23/aztaka-review/ Aztaka Review] by David Stone on [[Gamezebo]] (Jun 23, 2009)</ref><ref name="aztakademo">[https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2009/05/22/mictlan-aztaka-demo/#more-12019 mictlan-aztaka-demo] on [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]</ref> Aztaka was mentioned in an article about indie game development in March 2012 in Italian magazine [[The Games Machine (Italy)|The Games Machine]].<ref name="gamemachine">[https://archive.org/stream/the-games-machine-italia-284#page/n17/mode/2up/search/%22aztaka%22 the-games-machine-italia-284]</ref> Aztaka received the [[Game Tunnel]] "Gold award 2009".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100316052509/http://www.gametunnel.com/best-games-of-september-2009-article.php best-games-of-september-2009] on gametunnel.com (September 2009)</ref> According to the developer himself in 2011 the game earned not enough to cover the expenses and would have been therefore a [[commercial failure]].<ref name="revenue"/> On the other hand, [[Steamspy]] reported in 2017 40,000 owners which would indicate at least a covering of the expenses.<ref>[http://steamspy.com/app/37100 Aztaka] on [[Steamspy]] (January 2017)</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100211135929/http://aztaka.citeremis.com/ Official game website] (archived)

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{distinguish|Chorography}} [[File:Zorn Cachucha.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|Choreography for the Spanish dance [[Cachucha]], described using [[dance notation]]]]
'''Choreography''' is the [[art]] or practice of designing [[sequence]]s of movements of physical bodies (or their depictions) in which [[Motion (physics)|motion]], [[Visual appearance|form]], or both are specified. ''Choreography'' may also refer to the [[design]] itself. A '''choreographer''' is one who creates choreographies by practicing the art of choreography, a process known as ''choreographing''. Choreography is used in a variety of fields, including musical theater, [[cheerleading]], [[cinematography]], [[gymnastics]], [[fashion shows]], [[ice skating]], [[marching band]], [[show choir]], [[theatre]], [[synchronized swimming]], [[cardistry]], video game production and animated art. In the [[performing arts]], choreography applies to human movement and form. In [[dance]], choreography is also known as [[choreography (dance)|dance choreography]] or ''dance composition''.
==Etymology== The word ''choreography'' literally means "dance-writing" from the Greek words "χορεία" (circular dance, see [[choreia (dance)|choreia]]) and "γραφή" (writing). It first appeared in the American English dictionary in the 1950s,<ref> {{cite episode |title = Frankie Manning: Lindy Hop Pioneer |url = http://kuow.org/defaultProgram.asp?ID=11649 |series = Radio Intersection |credits = Presented by Amanda Wilde |network = [[KUOW-FM|KUOW]] Puget Sound Public Radio |location = [Seattle, WA] |airdate = 2006-10-26 |minutes = 12:31 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071012022429/https://www.kuow.org/defaultProgram.asp?ID=11649 |archivedate = 2007-10-12 |df = }} </ref> and "choreographer" was first used as a credit for [[George Balanchine]] in the Broadway show ''[[On Your Toes]]'' in 1936.<ref name=Taper180> {{cite book | last=Taper | first=Bernard | title=George Balanchine: A Biography | publisher=University of California Press | year=1996 | isbn=0-520-20639-8}}, p. 180 </ref> Before this, stage credits and movie credits used phrases such as "ensembles staged by",<ref> {{cite video | people = [[Mark Sandrich]] (Director) | date = 1935 | title = Top Hat | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0027125/ | publisher = [[RKO Radio Pictures]] | accessdate = 2007-08-08 | time = 00:01:15 | medium = DVD | quote = Ensembles Staged by [[Hermes Pan (choreographer)|Hermes Pan]] }} </ref> "dances staged by",<ref> {{cite video | people = [[Edward Cahn (director)|Edward Cahn]] (Director) | date = 1942 | title = Our Gang in "Melodies Old and New" | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0035055/ | publisher = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | accessdate = 2007-08-07 | time = 00:00:20 | medium = DVD | quote = Dancer Staged by [[Steven Granger]] and [[Gladys Rubens]] }} </ref> or simply "dances by" to denote the choreographer.<ref name=Taper180/>
==See also== {{portal|Arts}} *[[Movement director]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{commonscat-inline}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Choreography| ]] [[Category:Performing arts]]

{{Infobox video game | title = Chroma Squad | image = Chroma Squad logo.png | caption = ''Chroma Squad'' logo | developer = [[Behold Studios]] | publisher = Behold Studios
[[Bandai Namco Entertainment]] | engine = | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[OS X]], [[Linux]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[PlayStation Vita]] (Cancelled) | released = {{Unbulleted list|'''Microsoft Windows''', '''OS X''', '''Linux'''|April 30, 2015|'''iOS''', '''Android'''|May 18, 2017|'''Playstation 4''', '''Xbox One'''|May 19, 2017}} | genre = [[Tactical role-playing game|Tactical role-playing]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | director = | producer = Saulo Camarotti | designer = Mark Venturelli{{cite web|url=http://www.beholdstudios.com.br/press/sheet.php?p=Chroma%20Squad|title=Behold Studios|publisher=}} | programmer = Saulo Camarotti
Guilherme Mazzaro
Leonardo Prunk
Leonardo Leite | artist = Bruno Briseno
Betu Souza
Hugo Vaz | writer = | composer = Raphael Müller
Washington Rayk }} '''''Chroma Squad''''' is a [[Tactical role-playing game|tactical role-playing]] video game developed by Brazilian development team [[Behold Studios]]. The game is influenced by [[tokusatsu]] TV shows, particularly the ''[[Super Sentai]]'' and ''[[Power Rangers]]'' franchises. The game's development was funded via [[Kickstarter]].{{cite news|title=Chroma Squad - manager game with japanese-style super heroes by Saulo Camarotti|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1893273284/chroma-squad-manager-game-with-japanese-style-supe/|accessdate=4 May 2015|work=Kickstarter|date=4 May 2015}} The game was released on April 30, 2015 for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]] and [[Linux]]. Digital distribution is available through [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and [[GOG.com]]. ''Chroma Squad'' was released in early 2017 for [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] mobile devices, being published by [[Bandai Namco Entertainment]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/9/2/12771884/chroma-squad-ps4-xbox-one-vita|title=Super sentai RPG Chroma Squad is coming to consoles|last=Frank|first=Allegra|date=2016-09-02|website=Polygon|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-06}} A [[PlayStation Vita]] version was planned, however was ultimately cancelled.{{Cite web|url=https://www.destructoid.com/chroma-squad-coming-to-playstation-4-and-xbox-one-in-may-419851.phtml|title=Chroma Squad coming to PlayStation 4 and Xbox One in May|website=Destructoid|language=en|access-date=2017-03-24}} It was announced to be released on May 19, 2017 on PSN for PlayStation 4.{{Cite web|url=https://blog.us.playstation.com/2017/05/12/the-drop-new-playstation-games-for-5162017/|title=The Drop: New PlayStation Games for 5/16/2017|website=PlayStation.Blog|access-date=2017-05-15}} ==Plot== The game follows a team of stunt actors that tired of their previous job, decide to start their own [[Tokusatsu]] company, assisted by a mysterious artifact they find known as "Cerebro". ==Gameplay== Once the studio is established, the player must assign the actors, each with their own special traits, to their respective roles in the team and their suits' colors. Other features can be changed as the game progresses including the team's name, the name of their robot and their catchphrases. Each stage in the game is a different episode of the show in which the heroes fight a group of villains, sometimes followed by a battle between the team's giant mecha and an enlarged monster, and their performance during the episode take a direct impact on the show's ratings. High ratings increase the show's fanbase and revenue, which can be used to improve the studio and upgrade the team's equipment and mecha. The episodes are grouped into seasons and failure to complete the goals set by the sponsors at the end of each season will lead to a game over. The battles follow the heroes fighting initially in their normal selves, but later gaining the ability to transform, recovering their HP and obtaining special abilities. The "teamwork" function allows heroes to help each other during battle, be it reaching longer distances, dealing powerful attacks together, or combining their powers into a special attack that increases ratings when used to destroy the [[Villain of the week|monster of the week]]. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = PC: 75/100
PS4: 74/100 | Destruct = 8/10{{Cite web |url=https://www.destructoid.com/review-chroma-squad-291251.phtml |title=Review: Chroma Squad |publisher=[[Destructoid]] |last=Tolentino |first=Josh |date=4 May 2015 |accessdate=12 February 2018}} | Poly = 7.5/10{{Cite web |url=https://www.polygon.com/2015/5/19/8625287/chroma-squad-review-pc-steam |title=Chroma Squad review: faux faux Power Rangers |publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |last=McElroy |first=Justin |date=19 May 2015 |accessdate=12 February 2018}} | GI = 7/10{{Cite web |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/chroma_squad/b/pc/archive/2015/05/08/chroma-squad-review-game-informer.aspx |title=A Mighty Morphin' Tactical RPG - Chroma Squad - PC |publisher=[[Game Informer]] |last=Shea |first=Brian |date=8 May 2015 |accessdate=12 February 2018}} | rev1 = ''[[Shacknews]]'' | rev1Score = 8/10{{Cite web |url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/89392/chroma-squad-review-its-morphin-time |title=Chroma Squad Review: It's Morphin' Time |publisher=[[Shacknews]] |last=Perez |first=Daniel |date=1 May 2015 |accessdate=12 February 2015}} }} ''Chroma Squad'' received mixed to positive reviews from critics upon release. On [[Metacritic]], the game holds scores of 75/100 for the PC version (based on 21 reviews){{Cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/chroma-squad |title=Chroma Squad for PC Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=12 February 2018}}, and 74/100 for the PlayStation 4 version (based on 7 reviews).{{Cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/chroma-squad |title=Chroma Squad for PlayStation 4 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=12 February 2018}} {{Clear}} ==Rights dispute== The rights were disputed by [[Saban Brands]].{{cite web|last1=Farokhmanesh|first1=Megan|title=Chroma Squad dev in talks with Power Rangers creator over rights dispute|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/7/18/5916957/chroma-squad-power-rangers-dispute|website=[[Polygon (website)|''Polygon'']]|publisher=[[Vox Media, Inc.]]|accessdate=11 February 2017|language=English|date=18 July 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.chromasquad.com/}} {{portal bar|Video games|2010s}} [[Category:2015 video games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Cancelled PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:Cancelled PlayStation Vita games]] [[Category:Crowdfunded video games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Kickstarter-funded video games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:Power Rangers video games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Brazil]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox One games]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Clark and Michael | image = ClarkAndMichael.jpg | caption = Clark and Michael title screen | creator = [[Clark Duke]]
[[Michael Cera]] | director = Michael Cera
Clark Duke
[[Max Winkler (director)|Max Winkler]] | starring = Clark Duke
Michael Cera | endtheme = "Black Out" by [[British Sea Power]] | country = United States | language = English | network = [[CBS]] (distributed online) | first_aired = {{Dts||05|23}} | last_aired = {{End date|2007|07|25}} | num_episodes = 10{{cite web|url=http://www.collider.com/entertainment/interviews/article.asp/aid/4611/tcid/1 |title=Michael Cera and Clark Duke – Exclusive Video Interview |publisher=Collider.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-24}} | executive_producer = Matt Kaplan | producer = Michael Cera
Clark Duke
[[Seth Grahame-Smith]]
David Katzenberg
Max Winkler | editor = Michael Cera
Taylor Chien
Clark Duke | runtime = approx. 10 minutes{{cite web|url=http://www.clarkandmichael.com/blog/ |title=Clark And Michael |publisher=Clark And Michael |date= |accessdate=2012-07-24}} | website = production = EYE NET WORKS INC. distributor = You-Tube }} '''''Clark and Michael''''' is a [[CBS]] [[Internet television]] series created by and starring [[Clark Duke]] and [[Michael Cera]]. The series takes the form of a [[mockumentary]] following Duke and Cera's ambitions to write and sell a [[Television pilot|pilot]] for a television series. ==Style== Duke and Cera play fictionalized versions of themselves, Cera describing the characters as "more idiotic and more deluded".{{cite web|last=Chattman |first=Jon |url=http://thecheappop.com/2007/05/04/arrested-developments-michael-cera/ |title=welcome to thecheappop.com...your daily dose of pop culture and mustache envy » Blog Archive » Arrested Development’s Michael Cera |publisher=Thecheappop.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-24}} The series is a low-budget affair, filmed on handheld cameras by friends of the duo.{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/15.03/snackfilmtv.html |title=Wired 15.03: Snack Attack! |publisher=Wired.com |date=2009-01-04 |accessdate=2012-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730230854/http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/15.03/snackfilmtv.html |archivedate=2012-07-30 |df= }} The cameras are acknowledged by Clark, Michael and others, who will sometimes address them or those operating them; in one scene, an upset Michael shouts a cameraman out of the bathroom, after which Clark angrily points out to the crew that their contract states "no bathroom stuff". Boom mics are often visible, and the crew have also intervened in fights between Clark and Michael.{{cite web|url=http://www.clarkandmichael.com/index.php?id=3004 |title=Clark And Michael |publisher=Clark And Michael |date= |accessdate=2012-07-24}} ==Plot== Clark and Michael's ambition of producing their own television series is stated in the opening of the first episode, and forms the drive of the series. After being turned down initially, the pair come to terms with the fact that success will not be instantaneous, and continue to pursue new opportunities. Though their agent succeeds in scheduling a meeting to discuss their show with another network, Clark's drunken behavior changes their mind about picking up the show. Following this, the pair has a meeting with agent Ramsay, who recommends that Michael be made the "hero" of the series. Bothered by this, Clark reveals an idea for his own series, ''D.A. Dad'', to the crew, and begins pursuing the concept. Some time later, the pair are watching television together when they see an ad for ''D.A. Dad''. Clark reacts angrily, explaining that the show was his and the concept had been taken and produced by someone else. Michael is hurt that Clark would work separately from him, but the pair eventually reconcile their differences and their arrangement returns to normal. Michael takes up driving lessons, and takes an interest in one of his fellow students. The pair try to get [[Kenny Loggins]] to perform the theme song for their show, but can't get in touch with him. Michael only barely passes his driving test, and Clark informs him that he won't be driving his car. Regretting this overreaction, he makes it up to Michael with a game of [[minigolf]]. A meeting with another potential network ends poorly, unbeknownst to the two, when their arrogant behavior in general makes a bad impression on the executives. Clark soon makes it into Columbia University, and plans to move to [[New York City]] to attend. Yet Clark ultimately decides against university when they achieve their TV show dream, with CBS signing them up (as well as in real life). ==Guest stars== Several [[guest star]]s have made appearances in the series: * Some of Michael Cera's former co-workers from [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]'s ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' ** [[Tony Hale]] was featured in the first episode as an executive for the fictional ATC Family network, who turned down the pair's concept. ** [[Mitch Hurwitz]] (''Arrested Development'' creator) appeared as agent Ramsay, while Clark Duke's attorney, Jerry Lillard, was played by [[Andy Richter]]. ** When Michael attended driving lessons, he was taught by [[David Cross]]. *[[Eric Wareheim]] and [[Tim Heidecker]] (''[[Tom Goes to the Mayor]]'', ''[[Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!]]'') both have made appearances, with Heidecker as a martial arts instructor, and Wareheim's recurring role as their neighbor, Randy. * Comedian [[Patton Oswalt]] (''[[Ratatouille (film)|Ratatouille]]'') appears as a realtor who sells them an office building. * [[Jonah Hill]] (Cera's ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'' co-star) and [[John Francis Daley]] (''[[Freaks and Geeks]]'') appear as a rival television writing team. * [[Joe Lo Truglio]] appears as a deli store employee in episode 8. * [[Martin Starr]] (''Freaks and Geeks'') appears as an employee at a fast food restaurant, only in one episode. ==References== {{Reflist}} Clark and Michael was distributed by YouTube. ==External links== {{wikiquote|Clark and Michael}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081223134433/http://www.clarkandmichael.com/ www.clarkandmichael.com/] (official website) * {{IMDb title|0914803|Clark and Michael}} * {{Tv.com show|clark-and-michael|Clark and Michael|type=web}} [[Category:2007 web series endings]] [[Category:2007 web series debuts]] [[Category:CBS network shows]] [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:American web series]]

revision.text:
{{pp-pc1|small=yes}} In April 2013, [[Emma Sulkowicz]], an American fourth-year [[visual arts]] major at [[Columbia University]] in New York City, filed a complaint with Columbia University requesting expulsion of fellow fourth-year student and German national, Paul Nungesser, alleging he had raped them in Sulkowicz's [[dorm room]] on August 27, 2012.<ref name="aol._Colu">{{cite web|title=Columbia student says he didn't rape Emma Sulkowicz|last=Chapman|first=Isabelle|work=AOL.com|date=February 3, 2015|accessdate=May 29, 2016|url=http://www.aol.com/article/2015/02/03/columbia-student-says-he-didnt-rape-emma-sulkowicz/21138562/}}</ref> Nungesser was found 'not responsible' by a university inquiry. In 2017, the university issued a statement acknowledging that Nungesser experienced a "very difficult" time, promised to keep its gender-based misconduct policies fair, and settled Nungesser's lawsuit under undisclosed terms.<ref>{{cite web|last=Grace |first=Veronica |url=http://columbiaspectator.com/main/2017/07/13/columbia-settles-nungesser-title-ix-lawsuit/ |title=Columbia settles Nungesser's Title IX lawsuit - Columbia Daily Spectator |website=Columbiaspectator.com |date= |accessdate=2017-07-15}}</ref>
In May 2014, Sulkowicz filed a report against Nungesser with the [[New York Police Department]] (NYPD), who did not pursue charges.<ref name="waponun"/><ref name="Newsweek"/> The [[New York County District Attorney|district attorney's office]] interviewed both students, but did not pursue charges, citing lack of [[reasonable suspicion]].<ref name="Newsweek"/> Sulkowicz declined to pursue criminal charges any further,<ref name=VanSyckle20January2015 /><ref name="VanSyckle4September2014"/> and stated that NYPD officers were dismissive and had mistreated Sulkowicz.<ref name="goth_Spur">{{cite web|title=Spurned By Columbia, Student Says NYPD Mistreated Her While Reporting Rape|author=Christopher Robbins|work=Gothamist|date=May 18, 2014|accessdate=May 29, 2016|url=http://gothamist.com/2014/05/18/spurned_by_columbia_student_says_ny.php|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150524012014/http://gothamist.com/2014/05/18/spurned_by_columbia_student_says_ny.php|archivedate=May 24, 2015|df=}}</ref><ref name="VanSyckle4September2014"/>
After Columbia declined to take action against Nungesser, Sulkowicz focused their senior thesis on a work of [[performance art]] entitled ''[[Mattress Performance (Carry That Weight)]]'' which involved Sulkowicz carrying a 50-pound dorm mattress on campus to represent the painful burden rape victims carry throughout daily life, and in protest of what they described as Columbia University's mishandling of their sexual assault complaint.<ref name=wapo>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/10/29/its-hard-to-ignore-a-woman-toting-a-mattress-everywhere-she-goes-which-is-why-emma-sulkowicz-is-still-doing-it|title=It's hard to ignore a woman toting a mattress everywhere she goes, which is why Emma Sulkowicz is still doing it|work=The Washington Post|date=October 29, 2014|author=McDonald, Soraya Nadia}}</ref> Nungesser called Sulkowicz's allegations "untrue and unfounded" and described the mattress piece as an act of bullying intended to force him to leave Columbia.<ref name=VanSyckle20January2015>Van Syckle, Katie (20 January 2015). [http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/01/alleged-columbia-rapist-dismayed-by-sotu-honor.html "Alleged Columbia Rapist 'Dismayed and Disappointed' by Accuser’s SOTU Invitation"], ''New York Magazine'', January 2015; accessed May 29, 2016.</ref><ref name="NYT"/>
In April 2015, Nungesser filed a Title IX gender discrimination lawsuit against Columbia, its board of trustees, its president [[Lee Bollinger]], and Sulkowicz's supervising art professor [[Jon Kessler]], alleging their negligence in preventing his alleged harassment.<ref name="Newsweek">{{cite news|last1=Kutner|first1=Max|title=The Anti-Mattress Protest: Paul Nungesser’s Lawsuit Against Columbia University|url=http://www.newsweek.com/anti-mattress-protest-paul-nungessers-lawsuit-against-columbia-university-326319|accessdate=May 29, 2016|publisher=Newsweek|date=April 28, 2015}}</ref><ref name="abcnews.go.com">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/columbia-student-alleges-gender-bias-rape-claim-tossed-30542783|title=Correction: Columbia University-Gender Bias Suit Story|first=Larry|last=Neumeister|date=April 24, 2015}}</ref> Nungesser was represented by Title IX campus due process attorney Andrew Miltenberg.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/07/13/columbia-university-settles-title-ix-lawsuit-with-former-student-involving-mattress-girl-case/|title=Columbia University settles Title IX lawsuit with former student involving ‘mattress girl’ case|last=Shapiro|first=T. Rees|date=2017-07-13|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-09-26|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
In the documents of the complaint, Nungesser stated Sulkowicz's allegation of rape was false, citing as evidence behavior Nungesser said was counterintuitive, such as friendly texts Sulkowicz sent Nungesser days after the alleged attack occurred.<ref name="DailyBeast"/> The complaint argued Sulkowicz's allegation was made in response to unreciprocated desire for a serious relationship, therefore allowing the performance was harassment and a violation of his student rights. When questioned about the lawsuit, Sulkowicz said that it was "full of lies."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/paul-nungesser-lawsuit-columbia-sulkowicz-452241|title=Paul Nungesser’s lawsuit against Columbia over Emma Sulkowicz’s "mattress protest" returns to court|date=2016-04-25|work=Newsweek|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en}}</ref> Federal District Court Judge [[Gregory H. Woods]] dismissed the lawsuit<ref name="huff_Laws1">{{cite web|title=Lawsuit Against Columbia Over Mattress Protest Is Dismissed|author=Tyler Kingkade|work=The Huffington Post|date=2016-03-12|accessdate=2016-05-04|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/paul-nungesser-lawsuit-dismissed_us_56e43ae7e4b0b25c91822496}}</ref> but allowed Nungesser to refile an amended suit,<ref name="huff_Laws1"/> which was settled by Columbia in July 2017.<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite web|author=Kate Taylor |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/14/nyregion/columbia-settles-with-student-cast-as-a-rapist-in-mattress-art-project.html |title=Columbia Settles With Student Cast as a Rapist in Mattress Art Project |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date= |accessdate=2017-07-15}}</ref>
==Emma Sulkowicz== [[File:Emma Sulkowicz (cropped).jpg|thumb|185px|Sulkowicz in December 2014]] Emma Sulkowicz (born October 3, 1992 in New York City),<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMXp3RLOVNg "Carry That Weight"], Emma Sulkowicz interviewed by [[Roberta Smith]], Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art, December 2014, c. 48:50 mins.</ref> attended The [[Dalton School]] on the [[Upper East Side]] where they were an A student and competitive [[Fencing|fencer]]. In 2011 they began their undergraduate studies at Columbia University as a [[visual arts]] major.<ref name=Grigoriadis21September2014>Grigoriadis, Vanessa (September 21, 2014). [http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/09/emma-sulkowicz-campus-sexual-assault-activism.html "Meet the College Women Who Are Starting a Revolution Against Campus Sexual Assault"], ''New York Magazine''; accessed May 29, 2016.</ref> Sulkowicz identifies as [[Genderqueer|non-binary]] and uses [[singular they|they/them]] pronouns.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/02/12/is-there-a-smarter-way-to-think-about-sexual-assault-on-campus|title=Is There a Smarter Way to Think About Sexual Assault on Campus?|last=Tolentino|first=Jia|date=2018-02-05|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en|issn=0028-792X}}</ref>
==Paul Nungesser== Paul Jonathan Nungesser (German: Nunge[[ß]]<nowiki/>er;<ref>Christoph Cadenbach: [http://sz-magazin.sueddeutsche.de/texte/anzeigen/42729/Nachtschatten Nachtschatten], Süddeutsche Zeitung Magazin, Heft 5/2015.{{de icon}}</ref><ref>Ulrike Demmer, Susann Remke: [http://www.focus.de/panorama/welt/politik-und-gesellschaft-ich-habe-emma-nicht-vergewaltigt_id_4456606.html "Ich habe Emma nicht vergewaltigt"], Focus Magazin Nr. 7/2015.{{de icon}}</ref> born 1991 in Berlin) is a German citizen who studied [[architecture]] at Columbia.<ref name="NYT"/><ref name=DailyBeast/>
==Allegations== ===Allegations by Sulkowicz=== On April 18, 2013, Sulkowicz reported to Columbia's Office of Gender-Based and Sexual Misconduct that, on the first day of their [[sophomore year]] on August 27, 2012, in Sulkowicz's dorm room, they were raped by fellow student Nungesser.<ref name=NYT3May2014/><ref name="EmmaParentsLetter">{{cite web|url=http://columbiaspectator.com/opinion/2014/10/02/open-letter-president-bollinger-and-board-trustees|title=An open letter to President Bollinger and the board of trustees|publisher=Columbia Spectator|date=October 2, 2014|accessdate=April 25, 2015|author1=Leong, Sandra|author2=Sulkowicz, Kerry}}</ref>
Describing the alleged rape, Sulkowicz said that what began as a [[consensual sex|consensual sexual encounter]] in Sulkowicz's room turned non-consensual. Sulkowicz alleged that Nungesser [[choking|choked]] them, slapped their face, held their wrists, and [[anal rape|anally raped]] them, while Sulkowicz struggled and told him to stop.<ref name=NYT3May2014/><ref name=Bogler16May2014>{{cite news|last1=Bogler|first1=Emma|title=Frustrated by Columbia’s inaction, student reports sexual assault to police|url=http://columbiaspectator.com/news/2014/05/16/frustrated-columbias-inaction-student-reports-sexual-assault-police|work=Columbia Spectator|date=May 16, 2014}}</ref> Sulkowicz said that after the alleged assault, Nungesser immediately left the room without speaking.<ref name="DailyBeast">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/02/03/columbia-student-i-didn-t-rape-her.html|title=Columbia Student: I Didn't Rape Her|publisher=The Daily Beast|date=February 3, 2015|accessdate=May 29, 2016|author=Young, Cathy}}</ref>
He and Sulkowicz both corroborate that they had consensual sex twice before, earlier in the year, but not anal sex. Nungesser said that the encounter in August was also entirely consensual, and he denied the allegations of violence, stating that they briefly had consensual anal sex, followed by other sexual activity, after which they fell asleep, saying he left the room early in the morning while Sulkowicz was still sleeping.<ref name="DailyBeast"/>
Afterwards they communicated via Facebook messages. Nungesser later described these messages as "amiable" and showed transcripts of these messages to [[Cathy Young]], a contributor for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' who has been critical of campus sexual assault activism.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kay|first=Barbara|title=Rape culture’s biggest victim may be honesty and truth|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/full-comment/barbara-kay-rape-cultures-biggest-victim-may-be-honesty-and-truth|publisher=''National Post''|date=May 22, 2015|quote=During the summer there was warm, affectionate Facebook chatter between them (screenshots provided to The Daily Beast).}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bazelon|first=Emily|title=Have We Learned Anything From the Columbia Rape Case?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/29/magazine/have-we-learned-anything-from-the-columbia-rape-case.html|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=May 29, 2015|quote=After The Daily Beast published the exchanges, Sulkowicz explained them to the website Jezebel, recalling, “I'm being irrational, thinking that talking with him would help me.”}}</ref> Sulkowicz expressed concern that the messages would be used to present them as unreliable, and stated they had sent them because they were upset and wanted to talk to him about the incident but decided against doing so.<ref name="Kaplan2015-02-04">{{cite news|last1=Kaplan|first1=Sarah|title=In Columbia University rape case, accuser and accused are now fighting it out in public|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/02/04/in-columbia-university-rape-case-accuser-and-accused-are-now-fighting-it-out-in-public|accessdate=February 17, 2015|publisher=The Washington Post|date=February 4, 2015}}</ref> By the time of Sulkowicz's last message, which they sent in March 2013, they said they had visited the university's Office of Gender-Based Misconduct and that they had asked whether they had tried talking to the accused. A university spokesperson said in February 2015 that its gender-based misconduct policy does not recommend informal resolution or mediation for such complaints.<ref name="DailyBeast"/>
In response to criticisms regarding the delay in reporting, Sulkowicz said they initially didn't report the incident to avoid emotional trauma.<ref name=time/>
===Allegations from others=== Three other complaints have been alleged against Nungesser: a second woman accused him of emotional abuse and nonconsensual sex during a months-long relationship, a third student accused him of non-consensually kissing her and touching her at a party, and a fourth accuser emerged in early 2015, a fourth-year male student who said Nungesser sexually assaulted him after an emotional conversation. The second accuser's investigation was discontinued after she said she was "exhausted by the barrage of questions" and stopped responding to emails from the University's Title IX coordinator for sexual assault investigations.<ref name="NYT"/>
In early 2013 Sulkowicz discussed the incident with "Natalie", Nungesser's former girlfriend. Natalie alleged that there had been non-consensual sex and emotional abuse during her relationship with Nungesser, which lasted from October 2011 to spring 2012. Nungesser denies that charge and describes their time together as a couple as a "difficult relationship".<ref name="DailyBeast"/> Sulkowicz said that the conversation with Natalie prompted them to file a formal complaint to the university. Sulkowicz filed a complaint on April 18, 2013 and Natalie filed one a few days later.<ref name="NYT"/><ref name="DailyBeast"/><ref name=Leong/>
The third complaint from a student identified as "Josie" was initially decided against Nungesser, with an assigned punishment of disciplinary probation, but Nungesser successfully appealed, citing procedural errors and problems with the admission of [[hearsay]]. Nungesser further appealed on grounds that his accuser had failed to demonstrate guilt by a "preponderance of the evidence" as required in campus hearings.<ref name="DailyBeast"/> He says the allegations, which were all brought within days of each other, were the result of [[collusion]] and are fraudulent. The three women said in interviews with ''[[The New York Times]]'' that they decided to file formal complaints with the school after they heard about one another's experiences.<ref name="NYT"/>
The fourth student, identified as "Adam", said he first reported the incident to the group to which they both belonged, and then he filed a Title IX complaint.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/02/alleged-columbia-rapist-accused-of-new-assault.html|title=Male Columbia Student Says Alleged Rapist in ‘Mattress Girl’ Case Assaulted Him Too|last=Roy|first=Jessica|date=February 6, 2015|publisher=''New York'' magazine}}</ref> Columbia also investigated the complaint and found Nungesser "not responsible". According to Cathy Young, the investigators found contradictions in Adam's statements and Facebook dialogs between the men.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://reason.com/archives/2015/05/20/columbia-rape-saga-lingers-after-mattres/ | title=As Another Accusation Bites the Dust, Columbia Rape Saga Takes New Turn | date=20 May 2015 | accessdate=6 June 2016 | author=Young, Cathy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Armus|first1=Teto|title=Paul Nungesser found "not responsible" for alleged sexual assault of male student|url=http://columbiaspectator.com/spectrum/2015/05/21/paul-nungesser-found-not-responsible-alleged-sexual-assault-male-student|accessdate=6 June 2016|publisher=Columbia Spectator|date=21 May 2015}}</ref>
==Outcome of Sulkowicz's hearing, Nungesser's first complaints== On October 29, the day after Nungesser's third accuser's hearing, one was scheduled for Sulkowicz's case. In November the university found Paul Nungesser "not responsible".<ref name="NYT">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/22/nyregion/accusers-and-the-accused-crossing-paths-at-columbia.html|title=Accusers and the Accused, Crossing Paths at Columbia University|work=The New York Times|date=December 22, 2014|author=Kaminer, Ariel}}</ref><ref name=Leong>{{cite web|url=http://columbiaspectator.com/opinion/2014/10/02/open-letter-president-bollinger-and-board-trustees|title=An open letter to President Bollinger and the board of trustees|work=Columbia Spectator|date=October 2, 2014|author1=Leong, Sandra|author2=Sulkowicz, Kerry}}</ref> Sulkowicz's request for an appeal was turned down by the dean.<ref name=time>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/99780/campus-sexual-assault-emma-sulkowicz|title='My Rapist Is Still on Campus'|work=Time|date=May 15, 2014|author=Sulkowicz, Emma}}</ref>
Sulkowicz and Nungesser both complained separately about the proceedings. Sulkowicz complained that Nungesser was granted months of postponements during the hearing, and that they were not allowed to discuss the case with anyone. Sulkowicz said that a university investigator asked inappropriate questions during the interview, and complained that the panel did not consider other allegations against the accused student.<ref name=NYT3May2014/> A graduate student who acted as Nungesser's official supporter during the hearing defended the panel, disputing that their questions were inappropriate, saying the questions "were extremely personal because they had to be".<ref name="DailyBeast"/>
Nungesser complained that he had not been allowed to introduce Facebook messages as evidence. Nungesser and Sulkowicz exchanged several messages in the days and weeks after the alleged rape. In one message, two days after the alleged rape, Sulkowicz accepted an invitation to a party from Nungesser, writing: "I feel like we need to have some real time where we can talk about life and thingz, because we still haven't really had a paul-emma chill sesh since summmmerrrr."<ref name=NYT3May2014/> Sulkowicz says they sent the messages because they were upset and wanted to talk to Nungesser about the incident.<ref name="jeze_Howt">{{cite web| title = How to Make an Accused Rapist Look Good| last = Ryan | first = Erin Gloria| work = Jezebel| date = 2015-02-06| accessdate = 2016-10-19| url = http://jezebel.com/how-to-make-an-accused-rapist-look-good-1682583526}}</ref><ref name="mic.com">Zeilinger, Julie (February 3, 2015). [http://mic.com/articles/109446/the-treatment-of-emma-sulkowicz-proves-we-still-have-no-idea-how-to-talk-about-rape "The Treatment of Emma Sulkowicz Proves We Still Have No Idea How to Talk About Rape"], mic.com; accessed May 28, 2016.</ref>
Reporter Katie Zavadski, writing for ''[[New York Magazine]]'', opined that amicable exchanges with an alleged attacker didn't disprove that a sexual assault occurred, and Cathy Young acknowledged that victims of sexual violence may cope with trauma in ways that could seem puzzling to outsiders.<ref name="DailyBeast"/><ref name="nymag">{{cite web|last1=Zavadski|first1=Katie|title=Alleged Rapist in Columbia Case Offers His Version of Events, Produces Message Transcripts|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/02/alleged-rapist-in-columbia-case-speaks-out-again.html|website=NYMag|accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref>
==Press break, publicity and federal complaint== The ''[[New York Post]]'' broke the story in December 2013, without naming either party.<ref>Palmeri, Tara (December 11, 2013). [https://nypost.com/2013/12/11/co-eds-rip-columbia-over-athlete-rape-probes/ Columbia drops ball on jock 'rapist' probe: students"], ''New York Post'', December 11, 2013; accessed May 29, 2016.</ref> On April 7, 2014 Sulkowicz appeared with U.S. Senator [[Kirsten Gillibrand]] (D-NY) at a press conference about [[campus rape|sexual assault on campus]], telling reporters that Sulkowicz had been raped.<ref>[http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2014/04/07/sen-kirsten-gillibrand-seeks-funds-to-fight-college-campus-sex-assaults "Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand Seeks Funds To Fight College Campus Sex Assaults"], CBS New York, April 7, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.gillibrand.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/after-taking-on-sexual-assault-in-the-military-gillibrand-joined-by-nyc-student-survivors-launches-new-effort-fighting-sexual-assaults-on-college-campuses Press release] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160607175841/https://www.gillibrand.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/after-taking-on-sexual-assault-in-the-military-gillibrand-joined-by-nyc-student-survivors-launches-new-effort-fighting-sexual-assaults-on-college-campuses |date=2016-06-07 }}, gillibrand.senate.gov, April 7, 2014.</ref>
On April 24, Sulkowicz and 22 other students (later joined by five others) filed a 100-page federal complaint alleging that Columbia University and [[Barnard College]] mishandled their sexual-assault complaints, in violation of [[Title IX]], a federal civil rights law to ensure gender equality on campuses.<ref name=Grigoriadis21September2014/><ref name=Bogler24April2014/> The complaint alleged that the universities were in violation of Title II, a provision against discrimination by a public body on the basis of disability,<ref>Pryal, Katie Rose Guest (January 15, 2015). [https://chroniclevitae.com/news/864-where-title-ix-meets-title-ii "Where Title IX meets Title II"], ''Chronicle Vitae''.</ref> and the [[Clery Act]], which requires federally financed universities to disclose campus crime statistics.<ref name=Bogler24April2014>Bogler, Emma (April 24, 2014). [https://web.archive.org/web/20140428070027/http://www.columbiaspectator.com/news/2014/04/24/students-file-federal-complaint-against-columbia-alleging-title-ix-title-ii-clery "Students file federal complaint against Columbia, alleging Title IX, Title II, Clery Act violations"], ''Columbia Spectator''.<p> Kingkade, Tyler (September 18, 2014). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/18/columbia-university-complaint-rape-victims_n_5836944.html "Columbia University Rape Victim Says She Was Forced Out Of School Twice"], ''The Huffington Post''; accessed May 29, 2016.</ref>
The Department of Education's [[Office for Civil Rights]] opened two investigations in January 2015 into the Title IX and Title II complaints against Columbia.<ref name=NYT3May2014>{{cite news|last1=Pérez-Peña|first1=Richard|title=Fight Against Sexual Assaults Holds Colleges to Account|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/04/us/fight-against-sex-crimes-holds-colleges-to-account.html|work=The New York Times|date=3 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/01/12/columbia-sexual-assault-investigation_n_6458872.html|title=Columbia University Is Under Federal Investigation For Sexual Assault Cases|work=The Huffington Post|date=January 12, 2015|author=Kingkade, Tyler}}</ref>
On May 3, 2014 an interview with Sulkowicz appeared on the front page of ''The New York Times''.<ref name=NYT3May2014/> For several days from May 7 onwards, Paul Nungesser's name was included within lists of "sexual assault violators" written on the walls or doors of campus bathrooms, or on flyers.<ref>Abby Abrams (May 13, 2014). [http://columbiaspectator.com/2014/05/13/list-sexual-assault-violators-written-hamilton-lerner-butler-bathrooms "List of 'sexual assault violators' written in Hamilton, Lerner, Butler bathrooms"], ''Columbia Spectator''.</ref><ref name=Spectator16May2014/> On May 14, Sulkowicz filed a report with the [[NYPD]].<ref name=Bogler16May2014/> Columbia's student newspaper, the ''[[Columbia Daily Spectator]]'', controversially published the accused student's name two days later.<ref name=Spectator16May2014>Abrams, Abby and Lau, Steven (May 16, 2014). [http://columbiaspectator.com/2014/05/16/why-we-published-name-alleged-rapist "Why we published the name of an alleged rapist"], ''Columbia Spectator''.</ref> The editors stated that they felt it would be "irresponsible to keep his name hidden", noting that Nungesser had been at the center of three sexual assault complaints as well as a number of fliers posted around campus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://columbiaspectator.com/2014/05/16/why-we-published-name-alleged-rapist|title=Why we published the name of an alleged rapist|work=Columbia Spectator|date=May 16, 2014|accessdate=October 30, 2014}}</ref> Nungesser said he agreed to a police interview at the [[Sex Crimes Unit]] in New York City in August, and that shortly after this the district attorney's office told him they would not be pursuing the case.<ref name=VanSyckle20January2015/><ref name="DailyBeast"/> Sulkowicz declined to pursue an investigation after they discovered the case could extend past graduation, when they would probably want to "erase all of [their] memories of Columbia".<ref name=VanSyckle20January2015 /><ref name="VanSyckle4September2014"/> Sulkowicz further stated that NYPD officers were dismissive and "badly mistreated" Sulkowicz.<ref name="goth_Spur"/>
==Sulkowicz's performance art piece== {{main|Mattress Performance (Carry That Weight)}} [[File:Emma Sulkowicz, Mattress Performance, 19 May 2015 (cropped).JPG|thumb|Sulkowicz (center right) carrying the mattress at graduation]] Sulkowicz created ''[[Mattress Performance (Carry That Weight)]]'' in the summer of 2014 for their [[senior thesis]] while at [[Yale University]] Summer School of Art and Music. Their first effort was a [[Video art|video]] of themself dismantling a bed, accompanied by the audio of them filing the police report, which they had recorded on their cellphone.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMXp3RLOVNg Smith 2014], c. 38:45 mins.</ref> The mattress later became the sole focus of the piece.<ref name="RobertaSmithNYT">{{cite web| title = In a Mattress, a Lever for Art and Political Protest| last = Smith | first = Roberta| work = The New York Times| date = 21 September 2014| accessdate = 2016-05-04| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/22/arts/design/in-a-mattress-a-fulcrum-of-art-and-political-protest.html}}</ref> Sulkowicz told [[New York Magazine|''New York'' magazine]]:
{{quote|I thought about how ... the mattress represents a private place where a lot of your intimate life happens; and how I have brought my life out in front for the public to see; and the act of bringing something private and intimate out into the public mirrors the way my life has been. Also the mattress as a burden, because of what has happened there, that has turned my own relationship with my bed into something fraught.<ref name="VanSyckle4September2014">Van Syckle, Katie (4 September 2014). [http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/09/columbia-emma-sulkowicz-mattress-rape-performance-interview.html "The Columbia Student Carrying a Mattress Everywhere Says Reporters Are Triggering Rape Memories"], ''New York Magazine''.</ref>}}
The {{convert|50|lb|abbr=out|adj=on}}, dark-blue, extra-long [[Twin bed|twin]] mattress used in the performance art piece is of the kind Columbia places in its dorms, similar to the one on which they allege they were raped. Sulkowicz spent the summer of 2014 creating the rules of engagement: Written on the walls of their studio in the university's Watson Hall, these state that they must carry the mattress whenever they are on university property; that it must remain on campus even when Sulkowicz is not there; and that they are not allowed to ask for help in carrying it, but if help is offered they may accept it.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMXp3RLOVNg Smith, December 17, 2014], from c. 39:57 mins; for Watson Hall, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l9hHZbuYVnU Sulkowicz, September 2, 2014], from c. 2:00 mins.</ref> In September that year they began carrying it on campus, which they say is a physically painful experience.<ref>Duan, Noel (September 9, 2014). [http://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a14546/columbia-university-sexual-assault-mattress-performance-emma-sulkowicz "Going From Class to Class With Emma Sulkowicz and Her Mattress"], Elle.com; accessed May 29, 2016.</ref> Sulkowicz later created another piece of performance art, [[Ceci N'est Pas Un Viol]] ("This is not a rape"), a website with an eight minute video of Sulkowicz having sex with an anonymous actor in a dorm room at Columbia University.<ref>Lux Alptraum, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/21/style/campus-sex-women-exposure.html There Is Life After Campus Infamy]", in ''The New York Times'', July 21, 2018</ref><!--Alptraum confirms not only the existence of the piece but its relation to the rape-->
==Nungesser's lawsuit== On April 23, 2015, Nungesser filed a sexual discrimination lawsuit against Columbia, its board of trustees, its president Lee Bollinger, and Sulkowicz's supervising art professor Jon Kessler. The suit alleged that the performance was bullying and constituted gender-based harassment, and argued that Columbia's offering course credit for the work violated his rights under Title IX. The suit sought damages for the harm Nungesser said he experienced to his reputation as a result of the performance.<ref name="abcnews.go.com"/><ref name = huffsuit>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/23/sexual-assault-lawsuit-columbia_n_7132602.html Student Accused Being 'Serial Rapist' Files Lawsuit Against Columbia And Art Professor, Associated Press/Huffington Post]</ref><ref name="Newsweek"/>
The suit argues that Nungesser had provided evidence that the encounter was consensual with lack of signs of physical or emotional trauma and text based messages where Sulkowicz responded to Nungesser positively after the encounter. The suit also faults Columbia University for awarding course credits for a project that accused him of rape.<ref name = msnbc>Irin Carmon (April 24, 2015), [http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/columbia-student-accused-rape-sues-university Columbia student accused of rape sues university], msnbc.</ref><ref name = msnbc /> The suit alleged gender based discrimination, arguing that Nungesser was "targeted because he is a male, and attacked for his (consensual) sexual activity."<ref name = msnbc /> Nungesser's suit also alleged that the publicity surrounding the case had harmed his job prospects.<ref name="news_Mans">{{cite web| title = Man sues uni for mattress rape protest| author = AP and Network Writers| work = NewsComAu| date = 24 April 2015| accessdate = 2016-05-04| url = http://www.news.com.au/world/north-america/paul-nungesser-is-suing-columbia-university-in-new-york-for-allowing-emma-sulkowicz-to-carry-a-mattress-around-suggesting-he-raped-her/news-story/266fb8250341e0bb82560910fb6d7a1c}}</ref>
The case was assigned to [[US District Court]] Judge [[Gregory Howard Woods|Gregory Woods]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.newyorklawjournal.com/this-weeks-news/id=1202724570874/Student-Accused-of-Rape-by-Former-Friend-Sues-Columbia?mcode=1202615038803&curindex=30 | title=Student Accused of Rape by Former Friend Sues Columbia | publisher=''[[New York Law Journal]]'' | date=April 27, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015 | author=Neumeister, Larry}}</ref> Woods dismissed the case in March 2016, but allowed Nungesser another attempt.<ref name="huff_Laws1"/> Nungesser issued an amended complaint in April 2016. The amended complaint argued that Columbia University's sexual assault policies promoted a stereotype of the "sex-driven male", and constituted gender based discrimination in violation of [[Title IX]]. On March 24, 2017 Woods dismissed Nungesser's re-filed complaint, ruling that Nungesser had failed to state an actionable claim against Columbia University.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kutner|first1=Max|title=Court throws out Paul Nungesser's ‘anti-male’ lawsuit against Columbia, for good.|url=http://www.newsweek.com/paul-nungesser-columbia-lawsuit-dismissed-sulkowicz-mattress-574110|accessdate=8 May 2017|agency=Newsweek|date=2017-03-25}}</ref> After having the lawsuit dismissed twice, Nungesser had prepared an appeal, but he eventually agreed to settle with the university in July 2017.<ref name="waponun">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/07/13/columbia-university-settles-title-ix-lawsuit-with-former-student-involving-mattress-girl-case/|title=Columbia University settles Title IX lawsuit with former student involving ‘mattress girl’ case|last=Shapiro|first=T. Rees|date=July 13, 2017|publisher=''The Washington Post''|access-date=July 16, 2017}}</ref><ref name="timenun">{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4858979/columbia-university-paul-nungesser-mattress-girl-emma-sulkowicz/|title=Columbia Settles Lawsuit Brought by Former Student Accused of Sexual Assault by 'Mattress Girl'|last=Trautwein|first=Catherine|date=July 14, 2017|publisher=''Time''|access-date=July 16, 2017}}</ref> The terms of the settlement were confidential.<ref name="waponun"/><ref name="timenun"/>
===Commentary on lawsuit=== Robby Soave, an editor for ''[[Reason.com]]'', commented that Nungesser was "flipping the script" by basing his suit on Title IX, because "many alleged victims of rape who believe that they were deprived of justice have turned to Title IX when they assert that their universities are failing to honor federal requirements."<ref name="Reason.com">Soave, Robby (April 30, 2015), [http://reason.com/blog/2015/04/30/mattress-girl-lawsuit-can-paul-nungesser Mattress Girl Lawsuit: Can Paul Nungesser Beat Columbia in Court? Experts Weigh In - "His time at college and future have been shattered"], Reason.</ref>
Some commentators expressed skepticism that Nungesser's claim would succeed in court. [[Megan McArdle]] commented on the Title IX complaint in ''[[Bloomberg View]]'' saying, "I don't find (Nungesser's) litany of complaints particularly compelling", and stated that they believed the gender discrimination claim was unlikely to succeed. McArdle concluded by suggesting that Nungesser may not have intended to win the suit or to silence Sulkowicz, but instead to "force the media to pay a little attention to his side of the story, something that didn't happen during the many long months of Sulkowicz's campaign to name and shame him."<ref>Megan McArdle: [http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2015-04-27/accused-gets-his-say-in-columbia-rape-case Accused Gets His Say in Columbia Rape Case], Bloomberg View, April 27, 2015.</ref> Slate columnist Nora Caplan-Bricker questioned whether the suit could succeed, noting that courts have previously dismissed similar suits in which men accused of sexual assault claimed that they were victims of gender discrimination.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Caplan-Bricker|first1=Nora|title=Paul Nungesser Tries Again To Sue Columbia ... Using a Strategy That Has Never Worked Before|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2016/04/27/paul_nungesser_refiles_title_ix_lawsuit_against_columbia_university_over.html|accessdate=8 May 2017|agency=Slate.com|date=2016-04-27}}</ref>
Cathy Young, commenting on the dismissal of Nungesser's suit in the ''New York Post'', conceded that "Nungesser's case is more of an uphill battle than most", but nevertheless argued that she hoped "the lawsuit goes forward — not only on Nungesser’s behalf, but for the sake of truth-seeking about a tangled case that raises important issues."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=Cathy|title=Exposing rank injustice in the Columbia ‘mattress girl’ case|url=https://nypost.com/2016/03/18/exposing-rank-injustice-in-the-mattress-girl-case/|accessdate=8 May 2017|publisher=New York Post|date=2016-03-08}}</ref>
[[Amanda Marcotte]], in a column for the news site [[Talking Points Memo]], criticized Nungesser's decision to pursue a claim under Title IX rather than file a libel suit, and characterized the suit as a "nuisance lawsuit"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Marcotte|first1=Amanda|title=Targeting Columbia's anti-rape activists|url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/cafe/lawsuit-rape-columbia-emma-sulkowicz|website=Talking Points Memo|accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref> This characterization was disputed by Samantha Harris of the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education, who instead argued that the suit demonstrated the problem with requiring universities to investigate accusations of sexual assault, cautioning that "until something changes, we are likely to see more cases like this one."<ref name="thefire">{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Samantha|title=This is what a broken system looks like|url=https://www.thefire.org/this-is-what-a-broken-system-looks-like|website=thefire.org|accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref>
===Responses from Sulkowicz and Columbia University=== Sulkowicz responded to the lawsuit by saying it is "ridiculous that Paul would sue not only the school but one of my past professors for allowing me to make an art piece" and saying that Nungesser has made "continued public attempts to smear my reputation".<ref>{{cite news|title=Columbia Student Sues University, Says Rape Accuser Has Ruined His Reputation|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2015/04/23/columbia-university-lawsuit-mattress-rape-allegation|accessdate=April 24, 2015|publisher=CBS New York|date=April 23, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/male-student-sues-columbia-university-for-genderbased-harassment-after-alleged-mattress-performance-rape-victim-emma-sulkowicz-went-public-with-claims-10201388.html|title=Male student sues Columbia University for 'gender-based harassment' after alleged 'Mattress Performance' rape victim Emma Sulkowicz went public with claims|first=Heather|last=Saul|date=April 24, 2015}}</ref>
The school, via one of its spokespeople, had no official comment on the lawsuit, and Kessler also declined to comment,<ref>Emanuella Grinberg, [http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/27/living/feat-columbia-mattress-project-lawsuit/ Columbia student accused of rape sues over accuser's performance art]. CNN, April 28, 2015.</ref> although Columbia University president Bollinger offered a general statement: "The law and principles of academic freedom allow students to express themselves on issues of public debate; at the same time, our legal and ethical responsibility is to be fair and impartial in protecting the rights and accommodating the concerns of all students in these matters."<ref>{{cite news|title=Columbia student cleared of rape sues school|url=http://www.aol.com/article/2015/04/25/columbia-student-cleared-of-rape-sues-school/21176390|accessdate=May 29, 2016|publisher=AOL News|date=April 25, 2015}}</ref>
On July 14, 2017, Columbia and Nungesser agreed to settle the lawsuit for an undisclosed amount.<ref>{{cite news|author=T. Rees Shapiro |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/07/13/columbia-university-settles-title-ix-lawsuit-with-former-student-involving-mattress-girl-case/ |title=Columbia University settles Title IX lawsuit with former student involving ‘mattress girl’ case |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date= |accessdate=2017-07-15}}</ref> The university said in a statement: “Columbia recognizes that after the conclusion of the investigation, Paul’s remaining time at Columbia became very difficult for him and not what Columbia would want any of its students to experience. Columbia will continue to review and update its policies toward ensuring that every student — accuser and accused, including those like Paul who are found not responsible — is treated respectfully and as a full member of the Columbia community.”<ref name="nytimes1"/>
==Reception== Public opinion regarding the case and lawsuit has been mixed.
Cathy Young, who has written other "stories critical of campus anti-rape activism,"<ref name="Kaplan2015-02-04"/> criticized Columbia University for violating the defendant's rights to due process, commenting there was "certainly enough evidence to grant Nungesser the benefit of reasonable doubt not only in legal disciplinary proceedings, but in the court of public opinion".<ref name="mind_Did‘">{{cite web|title=Did ‘Mattress Girl’ Tell the Truth? Not Very Likely|author=Young, Cathy|work=Minding The Campus|date=June 4, 2015|accessdate=May 29, 2016|url=http://www.mindingthecampus.org/2015/06/did-mattress-girl-tell-the-truth-not-very-likely}}</ref> [[KC Johnson]], history professor at Brooklyn College argued that Sulkowicz's performance violated Columbia University's policy instructing participants in campus hearings to “make all reasonable efforts to maintain the confidentiality/privacy of the involved parties".<ref name="Reason.com"/><ref name="Johnson">{{cite web|url=http://www.mindingthecampus.org/2015/04/male-in-mattress-case-sues-columbia/|title=Male in 'Mattress Case' sues Columbia|author=KC Johnson|date=April 25, 2015|work=Minding the Campus|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> After Sulkowicz accused Cathy Young and Paul Nungesser of invading their privacy while reporting on the accusation, ''[[National Review]]'' columnist Ian Tuttle wrote Sulkowicz wanted "to make claims about another person that cannot be challenged, checked, questioned, or doubted."<ref name="nati_‘Mat">{{cite web|title='Mattress Girl' Is a Perfect Icon for the Feminist Left|author=Tuttle, Ian|work=National Review Online|date=2015-05-20| accessdate=2016-05-03|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/418686/mattress-girl-perfect-icon-feminist-left-ian-tuttle}}</ref> Columnist and political analyst [[Mona Charen]] was critical of Sulkowicz, and said that "it seem[ed] highly likely that Sulkowicz is shading the truth".<ref name="thef_What">{{cite web|title=What The Left And Right Don't Get About Campus Rape|author=Mona Charen|work=The Federalist|date=2015-08-31|accessdate=2016-05-04|url=http://thefederalist.com/2015/08/31/what-the-left-and-right-dont-get-about-campus-rape}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Charen |first1=Mona |title=It’s High Time Columbia’s Mattress Girl Was Discredited |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2017/08/columbia-university-mattress-girl-emmas-sulkowicz-paul-nungesser-lawsuit-rape-accusation-exonerated/ |accessdate=24 September 2018 |work=National Review |date=4 August 2017}}</ref> Janet Halley, a professor at Harvard Law School, commented that Columbia University's promise to review its policies was "a confession" that it thinks it made a mistake in how it dealt with the case.<ref>{{cite website|title=Columbia Settles With Student Cast as a Rapist in Mattress Art Project|date=14 July 2017|website=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/14/nyregion/columbia-settles-with-student-cast-as-a-rapist-in-mattress-art-project.html}}</ref>
Erin Gloria Ryan of [[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]] supported Sulkowicz, criticizing Young and accusing her of invoking a "perfect victim" narrative that relied on inaccurate stereotypes about how sexual assault victims should behave.<ref name="jeze_Howt"/> Senator [[Kirsten Gillibrand]] invited Sulkowicz to a [[State of the Union]] address in an effort to "further amplify" their voice, saying that activists like them "shine a light on the scourge of sexual assault" on college campuses.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/01/sulkowicz-was-let-down-by-state-of-the-union.html |title=Emma Sulkowicz Was ‘Let Down’ by Obama SOTU Speech |last=Katie |first=Van Syckle}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/rep-kirsten-gillibrand/carrying-their-weight-giv_b_6516630.html |title=Carrying Their Weight: Giving Voice to Survivors of Campus Sexual Assault}}</ref> When the lawsuit was settled, Dana Bolger, co-founder of [[Know Your IX]], expressed concern, saying she hoped universities wouldn't take the result "as a sign that they should be cracking down on student activism".<ref name="nytimes1"/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Columbia University rape allegation}} [[Category:2013 controversies]] [[Category:2014 controversies in the United States]] [[Category:Columbia University]] [[Category:Media-related controversies in the United States]] [[Category:2010s controversies in the United States]]

'''Dance Research Forum Ireland''' was founded in 2003. It is a non-profit inter-disciplinary society for scholarship of dance, in all its manifestations, in [[Ireland]] and its diaspora. It was formed by [[Dr. Catherine Foley]] of the [[University of Limerick]], who was the initial chairperson, with [[Michael Seaver]] vice-chair and Victoria O'Brien, secretary. At present Dr. Foley is chairperson, [[Orfhlaith Ni Bhriain]] is vice-chair and Olive Beecher is secretary.
The 1st International Conference was hosted by the Irish World Academy of Music and Dance at the University of Limerick in 2006.
==External links== * [http://www.danceresearchforumireland.org/ Official website]
{{dance-stub}}
